sense.name: paid position
sense.commentary: A regular position that usually earns money. A career. Does not refer to actual work or responsibility, only a position.
sense.examples: John had trouble finding a job after he graduated with a Linguistics major. My summer job as a lifeguard was a real pain in the butt. When the economy goes sour, lots of people can lose their jobs.

sense.name: task
sense.commentary: The actual work that a person does. Refers to an activity, not a position. Can be a regular activity or a specific piece of work; either paid or unpaid.
sense.examples: When I worked as a lifeguard, my job was to watch the pool. He came to work and did his job every day. It's a tough job, but somebody's got to do it. You did a good job on that midterm. This looks like a job for Superman! Painting the barn is going to be a huge job. I brought my wife to the job site (the site where the task takes place).

sense.name: being at work
sense.commentary: The state of being at work. Probably only used in the expression "on the job".
sense.examples: Intelli-Soft has had a record number of on-the-job accidents this month.

sense.name: object being worked on
sense.commentary: Probably a rare usage; an object that is the subject of a job.
sense.examples: I held the job in my left hand and worked on it with my left.

sense.name: a difficulty
sense.commentary: A general way of referring to something difficult or problematic.
sense.examples: It's always a job to contact him when he's eating.

sense.name: destruction
sense.commentary: An act of destruction. Probably only used in the expression "do a job on". This is a specific kind of task.
sense.examples: That barber really did a job on your hair, John.

sense.name: robbery
sense.commentary: The act of robbing or burglarizing; pulling off a caper. This is a specific kind of task.
sense.examples: The gang pulled off a bank job in St. Louis.

sense.name: Biblical figure
sense.commentary: A character in the Old Testament who suffers a lot. Also used in a metaphoric way for other long-suffering people.
sense.examples: And Job did sacrifice three oxen to the Lord, though the Lord did afflict him with boils. The prisoner, unjustly convicted of murder, was a patient and Job-like figure.

sense.name: Biblical book
sense.commentary: Part of the title of a book in the Bible. Though the title is named after the character Job, this sense does not refer to him. Used frequently as a shorthand for quotations.
sense.examples: "All the days of my appointed time shall I wait, till my change come," (Job 14:14). John entertained his little brother by reading aloud from the Book of Job.

sense.name: computer program
sense.commentary: In computer science, a program application that may consist of several steps but is a single logical unit.
sense.examples: I wrote a nifty job for Windows that automatically emails itself to everyone in your address book.
